source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 corrosion kinetics are characterized by the succession of two laws: the pretransition and the post-transition regimes. As a first approximation, the base mechanisms are represented by a cubic law in pre-transition phase and a linear law in post-transition phase [2]

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: The experimental results indicate an increase in cladding corrosion that is caused by lithium enrichment in the oxide layers formed [2,4]. Overconcentration mechanisms under boiling are linked to the thermo-hydraulic conditions in a region close to the wall as well as to the porous structure of zirconia
corrosion_data: increased corrosion due to lithium enrichment

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: The influence of boiling on Zircaloy-4 corrosion varies according to the oxidation phase reached. In fact, the various boiling regimes (nucleate or generalized boiling) only have a slight influence on cubic kinetics in the pre-transition regime

extra_properties.corrosion_independence: practically independent of void fraction variations in pre-transition

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: Analyses of pre-transition oxide layers by secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) reveal lithium enrichment at the oxide/water interface. The morphology of oxide formed before the transition time prevents significant diffusion of lithium in the more protective oxide films (Fig. I)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: Boiling conditions in out-of-pile loop tests provide an almost constant assessment of the overconcentration factor of around 2 to 3 for void fractions at the wall varying from 5 to 35%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: At the same time, various analyses have shown an increase in lithium concentration in oxide films subjected to increasing void fractions (Fig. 2). The lithium increase in the oxide that has become porous in the post-transition regime leads to a uniform lithium distribution from the metal/oxide interface to the oxide/water interface (Fig. 1)
conditions: post-transition regime with increasing void fractions

extra_properties.lithium_distribution: uniform from metal/oxide to oxide/water interface

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk1
evidence_span: It was possible to define an acceleration factor of post-transition kinetics as a function of the void fractions applied to the claddings: Fa(t) = DS/DS₀
corrosion_data: acceleration factor as function of void fractions

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk2
evidence_span: corrosion enhancement factor versus boiling conditions
conditions: boiling conditions, various void fractions, 60-day tests
corrosion_data: acceleration factor increases with void fraction, up to 30% then more significantly beyond

extra_properties.corrosion_acceleration_factor: varies with void fraction and conditions

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Analysis of the corrosion results from the static autoclave and the out-of-pile loops has made it possible to show the effect of important parameters influencing the oxidation kinetics of zirconium-based alloy claddings
corrosion_formula: ds³/dt = K_pre e^(-Q_pre/RT_i) and ds/dt = K_post e^(-Q_post/RT_i)
corrosion_data: Pre- and post-transition corrosion kinetics models

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_022_chunk8

conditions: PWR primary coolant with increasing lithium content

extra_properties.corrosion_enhancement: up to 30% depending on fuel management

conditions: 360°C, LiOH solutions with/without boric acid, 4-day duration
